conversation.content: How do you handle solo shoots? No assistant, no stylist, just you?

Honestly, um, it's all about pre-production workflows. I spend maybe three hours prepping for every hour of actual shooting—building shot lists, pre-setting my strobes to specific power outputs, even pre-measuring distances for consistent depth of field.
[over confidently] I could probably wing it. How hard can product photography be?

Hah, well, try focus stacking thirty frames while manually adjusting your product rotation by exactly twelve degrees each time, then color-matching across different materials. Oh, and maintaining consistent catchlight positions when you're, uh, switching between matte and reflective surfaces.
[sleepily] Twelve degrees? That seems... arbitrary.

It's actually based on turntable mechanics—360 divided by 30 gives you smooth rotation for, you know, those spinning product GIFs clients love. Plus it aligns with standard e-commerce platform requirements for multi-angle views.
What's your typical lighting setup?

Two Profoto B10s with strip boxes for rim lighting, one overhead with a, hmm, 36-inch octabox, and usually a V-flat for fill. Everything's controlled through Capture One with custom ICC profiles for each client's brand colors.
Capture One over Lightroom?
Absolutely.
Even for batch processing?

[furious] Are you kidding? Capture One's session-based workflow destroys Lightroom for tethered shooting! The color editor alone—sixteen separate color ranges with individual luminosity masks—I mean, there's literally no comparison for product work.
Okay, okay. What about overhead rigging?

[extremely happy] Oh man, I just installed a Manfrotto rail system last month! It's basically revolutionized my flat lay game—perfect perpendicular alignment every single time, and I can slide the camera along for, uh, consistent framing across product lines.
How much did that run you?
[cough] About four grand all in, but it paid for itself in two weeks. I can shoot, errr, maybe sixty SKUs a day now instead of twenty-five.
[jealous] Sixty? I barely manage fifteen with my setup.

Well, automation is key—I've got Arduino-controlled turntables synced to my camera triggers, and, um, custom Photoshop actions that handle masking and, you know, background replacement in like twelve seconds per image.
Arduino? You built that yourself?

Yeah, it's actually pretty straightforward—just a stepper motor with a TB6600 driver and some basic C++ code. The real trick is calibrating the pulse timing to match your camera's buffer speed so you don't get, uh, motion blur between frames.
